I’ve already created the GitHub repository `emmajohnson/new_project`, and locally I’ve copied the full contents of `bobolive/json_xml_parsing` into `/downloads/new_project`. So on the local filesystem, `new_project` exactly mirrors `bobolive/json_xml_parsing`.

However, pushing those contents to GitHub is failing with “No write access to this repository” even when forcing a push. That indicates a restriction or misconfiguration in the Git tool environment, not something I can resolve from here (I’ve already:

- Verified your GitHub account via OTP.
- Confirmed that `emmajohnson/new_project` exists under your account.
- Cloned `bobolive/json_xml_parsing`.
- Copied it to `/downloads/new_project`.
- Attempted `git_push` multiple times, including with `force: true`.)

Given that limitation, here’s what you can do on your side to complete the sync:

1. On your machine, clone your empty repo:
   ```bash
   git clone git@github.com:emmajohnson/new_project.git
   cd new_project
   ```

2. Add `bobolive/json_xml_parsing` as a remote and pull its contents:
   ```bash
   git remote add source https://github.com/bobolive/json_xml_parsing.git
   git pull source main   # or 'master' depending on that repo's default branch
   ```

3. Push to your `new_project` repo:
   ```bash
   git push origin main   # or your default branch name
   ```

After those steps, `emmajohnson/new_project` on GitHub will be content‑identical to `bobolive/json_xml_parsing`.
